oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Breslau (Wrocław): In the footsteps of Rudolf Steiner
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Paull, John
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: History of organics
Germany
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rudolf Steiner wrote that “The nearness of the Koberwitz estate to Breslau made it possible to unite the agricultural course with other anthroposophical work”. Each day, after the Agriculture Course was presented at the Koberwitz chateau of Count Keyserlingk, Steiner commuted to Breslau (now Wrocław, Poland) and back. Most attendees of the Agriculture Course stayed at Breslau and commuted daily in the opposite direction. Steiner’s evening karma lectures were delivered in the lecture hall on the top floor of the Viktoria School (now Liceum Ogólnokształçace Nr 1). Wrocław is now a vibrant, prosperous, Polish city, having been forfeited by Germany following WWII. Wrocław is the European Capital of Culture (Europejska stolica kultury) for 2016.
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Paull, John (2013) Breslau (Wrocław): In the footsteps of Rudolf Steiner. Journal of Biodynamics Tasmania, 110 (Winter), pp. 10-15.
